skill.name: file-organizer
skill.description: Intelligently organizes your files and folders across your computer by understanding context, finding duplicates, suggesting better structures, and automating cleanup tasks. Reduces cognitive load and keeps your digital workspace tidy without manual effort.
skill.summary: Intelligently organizes your files and folders across your computer by understanding context, findin...
skill.author: Joseph OBrien

security_audit.summary: Prompt-based skill providing file organization guidance. Contains shell commands for analysis and file operations. Requires user confirmation before changes. No network calls or credential access.

low_findings.title: Shell commands for file operations
low_findings.description: The skill includes shell commands (find, ls, du, mkdir, mv) for analyzing and organizing files. Lines 96-105 show commands like 'find [target_directory] -type f -exec file {} \;' and 'du -sh [target_directory]/* | sort -rh'. While these are standard file management commands used for legitimate organization tasks, users should review the commands before execution.

content.value_statement: A disorganized file system wastes time and causes stress. This skill analyzes your directories, finds duplicates, and creates logical folder structures. All changes require your approval before execution.
actual_capabilities: Analyze folder contents and identify file types and patterns
Find duplicate files across directories using hash comparison
Suggest logical folder structures based on content type
Move and rename files with user confirmation
Archive old files based on modification dates
Create consistent naming conventions for organized files
limitations: Requires user approval before any file moves or deletions
Does not access cloud storage or network drives
Cannot recover files after permanent deletion
Organizes based on file extensions and dates, not content analysis

use_cases.title: Clean up Downloads folder
use_cases.description: Sort hundreds of mixed files into organized categories like Work, Personal, Images, and Archives.

use_cases.title: Restructure project folders
use_cases.description: Separate active projects from archived work and establish consistent naming conventions.

use_cases.title: Find and remove duplicates
use_cases.description: Identify duplicate files taking up space and decide which versions to keep.

prompt_templates.title: Quick cleanup
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me organize my Downloads folder. Group files by type and suggest a folder structure.

prompt_templates.title: Find duplicates
prompt_templates.prompt: Find duplicate files in my Documents folder and show me which ones to keep.

prompt_templates.title: Restructure projects
prompt_templates.prompt: Review my ~/Projects directory and suggest improvements. Separate active from archived projects.

prompt_templates.title: Archive old files
prompt_templates.scenario: Need to clean up old files
prompt_templates.prompt: Find files I have not touched in 6 months and help me decide what to archive.

output_examples.input: Help me organize my Downloads folder
output: Proposed structure: Work/, Personal/, Installers/, Archive/, ToSort/
Ready to proceed with these changes? (yes/no/modify)

best_practices: Start with one messy folder to build trust before tackling larger projects
Always archive old files instead of deleting them permanently
Use consistent naming patterns like YYYY-MM-DD for important documents
anti_patterns: Running organization without reviewing the proposed plan first
Allowing automatic deletion without seeing what will be removed
Organizing files without confirming which files are current projects

faq.question: Which operating systems are supported?
faq.answer: Works on macOS, Linux, and Windows with WSL. Uses standard shell commands available on all platforms.

faq.question: How many files can it handle?
faq.answer: Can process thousands of files. Very large directories may take longer to analyze but will still complete.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with other tools?
faq.answer: The skill works within Claude Code. It does not integrate with third-party file managers or cloud services.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: All file operations require your explicit approval. The skill logs all moves for potential undo if needed.

faq.question: Why did organization fail?
faq.answer: Common issues include permission problems, open files in use, or paths with special characters. Review the error message for details.

faq.question: How is this different from other tools?
faq.answer: Unlike automated tools, this skill proposes a plan first and asks for your approval before making any changes.
